H0.text: Hydroxyl groups are the groups between which hydrogen bonds hold together the parallel rows of cellulose chains.

H1.text: Disc groups are the groups between which hydrogen bonds hold the chains in cellulose together in parallel rows.

H2.text: Carbon groups are the groups between which hydrogen bonds hold the chains in cellulose together in parallel rows.

H3.text: Soda groups are the groups between which the chains in cellulose stack in parallel rows and are held together by hydrogen bonds.

A4.text: The multiple hydroxyl groups on the glucose from one chain form hydrogen bonds with oxygen atoms on the same or on a neighbour chain, holding the chains firmly together side-by-side and forming microfibrils with high tensile strength.
